Cedric Beust wrote:

> I disagree.  A lot of programs work based on random generations, so it
> should come as no surprise that tests can do that as well, as long as the
> failure can be reproduced when it occurs.
> 

I think we're in agreement here, but I don't think this is what the 
original poster was suggesting. I'm OK with randomly selecting data from 
a large input set (too large to test exhaustively) for testing provided 
that the selection is done prior to the construction of the unit test 
suite. i.e. from the generated tests you want to pick out any tests that 
fail and explicitly add them to the unit test suite. This is a 
reasonable thing to do, but it's not something that JUnit really lends 
itself to.

I think the original request was top randomly pick test data as part of 
the test suite itself, and I think that's a bad idea. At worst you're 
going to see unreproducible failures. At best, you're going to get a 
failure with enough information about the input data to enable you to 
hand construct a reproducible version if anybody's actually looking that 
closely at the results, which often they aren't. For instance, if I busy 
optimizing and debugging in package foo I may ignore test failures that 
randomly occur in package bar.

Another problem: the normal response to a test failure following a code 
change is to look at that change and see how that modification caused 
the problem. With random test data there's simply no guarantee that the 
last change did indeed cause the test failure. the failure could have 
existed completely independently of the change you made.

You can work around all these issues of course; but really, why should 
you? None of this is what JUnit (or unit testing in general) was 
designed to do . There are simpler, easier ways to solve this problem 
that don't involve running different tests every time you type "java 
junit.text.ui.TestRunner foo.bar.TestSuite."
